doc.title: Renewable fundamend fee structures
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Investment Companies Weekly Wrap Renewable funds amend fee structures Investment Companies Weekly Wrap Renewable funds a_2025-08-29

passages.text: This week, we highlight: 1) Octopus Renewable Infrastructure joins the list of renewable funds amending fee structures, 2) Foresight Solar Fund sells its stake in a pre- construction BESS asset and 3) Partners Group Private Equity reports H1 25 results

- Octopus Renewables Infrastructure Trust (EW): Revised management fee- Foresight Solar Fund (OW): Sale of pre-construction BESS asset at NAV- Partners Group Private Equity (UW): H1 25: Pick up in exit activity expected- Apax Global Alpha (OW): H1 25: -6.2% TR in H1
FIGURE 1. Chart of the week: Average management fee reduction across companies that have incorporated market cap into management fee calculations
Source: Company data, Barclays Research
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 14. Completed: 29-Aug- 25, 09:41 GMT Released: 29-Aug- 25, 09:45 GMT Restricted - External
European Investment Companies NEUTRAL Unchanged

This week, Octopus Renewables Infrastructure announced a revision to its management fee structure (see summary of announcement below). With this change, nearly all renewable infrastructure funds under our coverage have now adopted fee models that incorporate an element of market cap. We highlight the level of fee savings in Figure 1.

Year to date, 10 renewable infrastructure funds (11 including Ecofin US Renewables, not covered) have transitioned to new management fee structures. Bluefield Solar Income remains the only fund to implement fee changes, however, its board has announced that discussions are underway with the investment Manager regarding the level and basis of fee calculation.
The revised models typically calculate fees based on the lower of NAV or market capitalisation, or apply an equal weighting between the two. On average, changes have resulted in a cost saving of \(
FIGURE 2. Summary of fee changes announced in Renewable Infrastructure funds to date
Source: Company data, Barclays Research

Octopus Renewables Infrastructure Trust (EW): Revised management feeMarket Cap: £372m | Prem/(Disc) to NAV: - 30.2% | Div yield: 8.9%Octopus Renewables Infrastructure announced a revision to the investment management agreement, with rates now calculated on an equal weighting of 1) the average of the daily market capitalisation at each quarter and 2) the published NAV at each quarter. The original management fee consisted of 0.95% p.a. of NAV up to £500m, 0.85% p.a. of NAV > £500 million. The trend of management fee changes has been ongoing within renewable infrastructure funds, largely due to pressure from investors to base management fees on market cap (rather than NAV) to improve alignment.
Market Cap: £455m | Prem/(Disc) to NAV: - 24.4% | Div yield: 9.9

Foresight Solar Fund announced the sale of its \(50\%\) stake in the 50MW pre- construction BESS asset, Lunanhead, which was co- owned with Foresight Environmental Infrastructure. The transaction was completed in in line with the June 2025 carrying value. The sale follows the Q2 NAV announcement, where the asset was was written down by 0.1p (- 0.1% NAV impact). The original acquisition cost of the asset was £16.4m, although the value of this was written down last year due to falling prices for RTB BESS projects. The fund is considering options for its \(50\%\) stake in another 50MW pre- construction BESS asset, Clayfords.
Market Cap: £622m | Prem/(Disc) to NAV: - 24.6% | Div yield: 7.2%

Partners Group Private Equity announced interim results for the six months ending June 2025. The NAV per share was consistent with prior updates, with the fund posting a - 5.8% total return for the period (- 4.6% in Q1, - 1.2% in Q2). A modest 0.9% uplift in portfolio valuation was offset by FX headwinds of - 5.4%. Distributions totalled £40m during the period, including £31m from the sale of listed holdings. An additional c. £85m of proceeds are expected to be received from the sale of PCI and Techem announced earlier this year (see link), bringing the total realisations to c. 10% of the opening portfolio (FY24: 14%). Management indicated that distributions are expected to normalise to the high- teens as a percentage of NAV, with reinvestments guided at 8- 10% of NAV over the next 6- 12 months.

Available liquidity at period end stood at £128m, including £120m available on the RCF (£140m facility) versus commitments of £50- 65m expected to be drawn over the next 2- 4 years. LTM EBITDA growth decreased to 10% (FY24: 12%). Valuation multiples were in line with the March 2025 announcement, with EV/EBITDA at 18x and net debt/EBITDA at 6x.
Market Cap: £786m | Prem/(Disc) to NAV: - 17.6% | Div yield: 6.7%

Apax Global Alpha announced results for the six months to June 2025, with NAV per share in line with previous announcements at £2.29, reflecting a - 6.2% total return in H1 (+2.5% on a constant currency basis). LTM revenue and EBITDA growth were 10% and 13% respectively (FY24: 9% and 14%). Investments during the period totalled £101m of investments versus £29m of distributions, with a further £31m expected post period end. EV/EBITDA increased to 18.2x (Dec- 24: 17.8x), whilst net debt/EBITDA was stable at 4.6x (Dec- 24: 4.5x). The results announcement follows the recommended all- cash offer announcement last month at a 17% discount to NAV. For more, see Apax Global Alpha: Recommended offer at 17% discount to NAV, 22 July 2025

Fed put killed vol & prompted HF/systematic buying spree. Positioning higher in US, beware of Sep seasonality and pockets of froth. But still much dry powder to fuel BTD, melt- up & broadening if data hold. EU less hot & France a reality- check for crowded domestics but political risk likely contained. For more, please see Who Owns What: Fed put unleashed, 27 August 2025

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Valuation Methodology: Our 96p price target is based on a combination of our NAV total return valuation methodology (50% weighting) and a portfolio DCF (50% weighting). Our NAV TR methodology is derived by adding the present value of total returns (NAV growth plus dividends) less a 9.4% cost of equity over a five- year period to the next FY NAV per share. The cost of equity reflects a combination of a risk free rate (based on geographic exposure) and a risk premium to reflect our view on earnings visibility.

Risks which May Impe the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Risks to our price target include lower/higher power prices (both actual and forecast) and lower-/higher- than- budgeted portfolio generation. Changes to portfolio discount rates and regulatory risk could also impact NAV and result in a lower/higher price target.

Valuation Methodology: Our 85p price target is based on a combination of our NAV total return valuation methodology (50% weighting) and a portfolio DCF (50% weighting). Our NAV TR methodology is derived by adding the present value of total returns (NAV growth plus dividends) less a 8% cost of equity over a five- year period to the next FY NAV per share. The cost of equity reflects a combination of a risk- free rate (based on geographical exposure) and a risk premium to reflect our view on earnings visibility.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Upside risks to our price target include higher power prices, potential asset sales and a favourable outcome from upcoming electricity market reform. Downside risks to our price target include lower power prices (both actual and forecast) and lower- than- budgeted portfolio generation. Rising portfolio discount rates and regulatory risk could also impact NAV and result in a lower price target.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated. Nothing in these materials, including any images included therein, is intended to convey, suggest or indicate that Barclays considers or represents any product, service, person or body mentioned in these materials as meeting or qualifying for any ESG or sustainability classification, label or similar standards that may exist under ESG Regimes. Barclays has not conducted any assessment of compliance with ESG Regimes. Parties are reminded to make their own assessments for these purposes.
